title: 1Â  Introduction
text:
2 Introduction to Version control
What is version control?
Version control is a system that helps you track and manage changes to files over time. It lets you save different versions of your work, go back to earlier versions if you make a mistake, and work with other people without overwriting each otherâ€™s changes.
Imagine youâ€™re writing a paper. Every time you make a big edit, you save a new copy: paper_v1.docx, paper_v2.docx, paper_final.docx, etc.
Version control keeps track of these versions for you. Have you ever used the versions feature in Google docs when working on an article draft? Then youâ€™ve interacted with version control.
What is Git?
To keep track of versions of coding projects, programmers use a version control tool called Git. It runs on your computer and helps you:
You can think of Git like a very smart â€œsave gameâ€ system for your projects. Unlike in Google docs, our versions arenâ€™t automatically saved for us. We have to tell our computers when and how to save a new version.
How GitHub fits into this:
GitHub is a website that hosts Git repositories (your project + its history) online.
It lets you:
If Git is your notebook where you track all your work, GitHub is like an online library where you can store a copy of your notebook â€” and invite others to read it or even help you write it.

title: 1Â  Using a Terminal

2 Terminal
A short chapter to explain basic bash commands like ls, cd, mkdir, etc.
Terminal (Mac) and Git Bash (Windows) are programs that can run a shell, which is a text-based user interface where you type commands that your computer understands.
Developers use a shell to issue commands to their computer to do things, like to install programs, change what folder their are in, etc. Using a terminal program to use your computer can be confusing at first, but it will become second-nature as you progress through this class.
The shell programming language we will use for these text-based interactions is called Bash. Bash is a Unix-based program and most of the Internet runs on Unix (or Linux) computers.
Windows doesnâ€™t understand Bash at all without the help of another program. This is why we installed Git and Git Bash so we can all speak the same language.
Macs understand Bash natively, but some day they will change to a similar language called zsh. When you launch a shell on newer Macs you might get a message The default interactive shell is now zsh. To update your account to use zsh, please run chsh -s /bin/zsh. DONâ€™T DO THIS! JUST IGNORE IT. We will continue to use Bash. Later we will add a command to disable this message.

title: 1Â  Using a Terminal
text:
2.2 The terminal prompt
Before I adjusted it, I would see this when I launched my terminal:
COMM-A54338:~ ccm346$

The first part before the ~ is my computer name.
The part after the ~ is is my username.
Lastly we have the $. This is the â€œpromptâ€ where you type commands. You type your commands AFTER the $ and then hit Return on your keyboard to execute them.

In this book you might see examples of a command that includes an output. That first line will have the $ before the command so you know that it is a command, but DONâ€™T TYPE IN THE $. For instance:
$ pwd
/Users/ccm346/icj/myproject
Means you type in just pwd and then hit return.

title: 1Â  Using a Terminal
text:
2.3 Typing vs copy/paste
I encourage you to type commands into your terminal instead of copy and pasting them from the lessons. Build muscle and mind memory. Typing a command wrong and then having to figure out why it broke will help you learn it and remember it. If you just copy and paste blindly, then you wonâ€™t learn anything other than command-c and command-v.






I use the terms â€œfolderâ€ and â€œdirectoryâ€ interchangeably here. They are the same thing.

title: 1Â  Using a Terminal
text:
2.4 Print working directory
One of the hardest things to get a handle on when first working in the terminal is to figure out where you are on your computer. Itâ€™s important, because you can run commands on any file on your computer from where you are, but you gotta know where that is before you can do so. So, weâ€™ll use pwd, or â€œprint working directoryâ€.

In your Terminal, type and execute:

pwd
When I do this on my machine, here is what the command and response look like:
$ pwd
/Users/ccm346
Because Iâ€™m using my work computer my user directory is called â€œccm346â€. Yours might be your name or part of your name. This user directory is called your â€œhome directoryâ€. All of your computer files are stored inside your home directory.
When you launch a new terminal it starts you out inside this directory.

title: 1Â  Using a Terminal
text:
2.5 List directory
Letâ€™s see what is inside our home directory.

Do this:

ls
This will list everything in the directory you are in. Mine looks like this:
$ ls
Applications        Library         google-cloud-sdk
Creative Cloud Files    Movies          miniforge3
Desktop         Music           thingy.html
Documents       Pictures
Downloads       Public
It listed the names of all the folders and files of the directory Iâ€™m in. This is similar to opening a folder browser on your computer and then opening your home folder and looking inside of it.



Home directory

title: 1Â  Using a Terminal
text:
2.6 Flags
But sometimes, I want to know more information about the files, like their modification date. To do this, we introduce something called flags, which add nuance or detail to a terminal command. They start with a dash, and you can pile them on, as Iâ€™ll demonstrate.

First, try this:

ls -l






Important



That is â€œdash Lâ€, not a number 1. Watch the spaces, too.


My output looks like this:
crit:~$ ls -l
total 0
drwx------@   5 ccm346  AUSTIN\Domain Users   160 Aug 21  2022 Applications
drwx------@   4 ccm346  AUSTIN\Domain Users   128 Jul 10 10:54 Creative Cloud Files
drwx------@  23 ccm346  AUSTIN\Domain Users   736 Jul 11 13:18 Desktop
drwx------+  23 ccm346  AUSTIN\Domain Users   736 Jul 11 09:29 Documents
drwx------@   8 ccm346  AUSTIN\Domain Users   256 Jul 12 13:06 Downloads
drwx------@ 101 ccm346  AUSTIN\Domain Users  3232 Jun 13 14:23 Library
drwx------+   6 ccm346  AUSTIN\Domain Users   192 Oct  3  2022 Movies
drwx------+   4 ccm346  AUSTIN\Domain Users   128 Nov  9  2021 Music
drwx------+   5 ccm346  AUSTIN\Domain Users   160 Jul  2 10:29 Pictures
drwxr-xr-x+   4 ccm346  AUSTIN\Domain Users   128 Nov  5  2021 Public
drwxr-xr-x   21 ccm346  AUSTIN\Domain Users   672 Jun 23 09:08 google-cloud-sdk
drwxr-xr-x   15 ccm346  AUSTIN\Domain Users   480 Mar  3  2022 miniforge3
-rw-r--r--    1 ccm346  AUSTIN\Domain Users     0 Nov 14  2022 thingy.html
Well, thatâ€™s a lot of info, and much of it jibberish. Here is what each part of those lines means â€¦

drwxr-xr-x and similar is the permission information for a that file or folder. We arenâ€™t going to get into it here, but you can read more if you like.
The next number is the number of files inside the folder, sort of. If this is a file, the number will be â€œ1â€. If it is a folder, the number will always be at least â€œ2â€. Weâ€™ll come back to this.
Next is the owner of the file or folder.
Next is a permission level for the user when the file was created.
Next is the file size in bytes.
Next is the last modified date of the file or when a file was added to the folder.
File or folder name.


2.6.1 Hidden files
Letâ€™s add another flag to your command.

Do this:

ls -al
My list got a TON longer. I snipped out the middle part here:
crit:~$ ls -al
total 352
drwxr-x---+  54 ccm346  AUSTIN\Domain Users   1728 Jul 10 10:50 .
drwxr-xr-x    7 root    admin                  224 Jun 24 13:21 ..
srwxr-xr-x    1 ccm346  AUSTIN\Domain Users      0 Jul 10 10:50 .Box_EngineServer
srwxr-xr-x    1 ccm346  AUSTIN\Domain Users      0 Jul 10 10:50 .Box_StreemToSync

-r--------    1 ccm346  AUSTIN\Domain Users      7 Nov  5  2021 .CFUserTextEncoding
-rw-r--r--@   1 ccm346  AUSTIN\Domain Users  14340 Jul 11 09:31 .DS_Store
-rw-r--r--    1 ccm346  AUSTIN\Domain Users     35 May 22 14:09 .Rapp.history
-rw-r--r--@   1 ccm346  AUSTIN\Domain Users    510 Mar 30 11:45 .Renviron
-rw-r--r--    1 ccm346  AUSTIN\Domain Users     73 Nov  5  2021 .Rhistory
<snip>
drwx------@   5 ccm346  AUSTIN\Domain Users    160 Aug 21  2022 Applications
drwx------@   4 ccm346  AUSTIN\Domain Users    128 Jul 10 10:54 Creative Cloud Files
drwx------@  23 ccm346  AUSTIN\Domain Users    736 Jul 11 13:18 Desktop
drwx------+  23 ccm346  AUSTIN\Domain Users    736 Jul 11 09:29 Documents
drwx------@   8 ccm346  AUSTIN\Domain Users    256 Jul 12 13:06 Downloads
drwx------@ 101 ccm346  AUSTIN\Domain Users   3232 Jun 13 14:23 Library
drwx------+   6 ccm346  AUSTIN\Domain Users    192 Oct  3  2022 Movies
drwx------+   4 ccm346  AUSTIN\Domain Users    128 Nov  9  2021 Music
drwx------+   5 ccm346  AUSTIN\Domain Users    160 Jul  2 10:29 Pictures
drwxr-xr-x+   4 ccm346  AUSTIN\Domain Users    128 Nov  5  2021 Public

-rw-r--r--    1 ccm346  AUSTIN\Domain Users      0 Nov 14  2022 thingy.html

The -a flag means â€œallâ€ files and folders, including hidden ones. All the files or folders at the top that start with a dot like .Box_EngineServer are on the computer but not visible normally. There can be a lot of hidden them â€¦ I have 40+, far more than regular files and folders.

Letâ€™s list again with just the -a flag:

ls -a
Here is the top of my list:
crit:~$ ls -a
.
..
.Box_EngineServer
.Box_StreemToSync
.Box_SyncToStreem
.Box_UIServer
.CFUserTextEncoding
.DS_Store


2.6.2 Dot directories
But letâ€™s consider the first two returns:
$ ls -a
.
..
These are two special designations in the Unix world. A single period . designates â€œthis directoryâ€ and two periods .. designates the â€œparent directoryâ€, i.e.Â the folder â€œaboveâ€ this one. Every directory has these, so thatâ€™s why the ls -l always shows two items inside a directory, even if it is â€œemptyâ€ of regular files or folders.
We can use these â€œdotâ€ and â€œdot dotâ€ designations to move around into different directories, and to manage files in our current directories. They become super important when we make â€œpathsâ€ between files in our programs and web pages.
Letâ€™s see this â€œdotâ€ designation in action by opening our â€œcurrentâ€ folder in Finder. This command differs slightly depending on your OS.

macOSWindows



Do this command:

open .



Do this command:

start .



Since you are inside your â€œhome directoryâ€, this should open that folder in your Finder.






iCloud and One Drive



A word about cloud services like iCloud and OneDrive. We are going set up a place to store our projects so they are NOT backedup to cloud services. We do this for a couple of reasons:

Later projects in this class will include thousands of tiny files. The process of writing them back forth to the cloud service can affect computer performance.
Our projects use these files in order to function, and when they get off-loaded to the cloud then our code has problems working.

Donâ€™t worry â€¦ weâ€™ll back up your class work through Github.

title: 1Â  Using a Terminal
text:
2.7 Make directory
Next we are going to make a new empty folder to store all our class files using the mkdir command.

Do this:

mkdir icj

Then use ls again to see your new directory amongst the others.

Creating a directory like this is exactly the same as opening a desktop window on your Mac creating a new folder. Folders and directories are the same thing.

Cool, letâ€™s make another directory inside of icj.

mkdir icj/newdirectory

Now you can do an ls on the â€œicjâ€ folder to see what is inside it.

ls icj
It should show you newdirectory. Something like this:
$ ls icj
newdirectory
A couple of things about this:
You have listed the contents of the icj directory without being inside of it. You can list the contents of any folder on your computer if you know the path to it. In fact, you can do any command on any file or folder on your computer if you know its path. The path is the folder structure between where you â€œareâ€ in the terminal to where the new file/folder is.
If you name a directory with a space in it, youâ€™ll not get what you want unless you put quotes around it. Because of this, I avoid using spaces in files and folders and use - or _ instead. I avoid capitalization, too, because our folders become url names and sometimes caps mess it up, especially on PCs.

title: 1Â  Using a Terminal
text:
2.8 Change directory
Itâ€™s time to move into different folders within our terminal. The cd command lets us change directory.

Now, letâ€™s go inside the icj folder:

cd icj

Letâ€™s see what is inside:

ls
That should show you a result with the newdirectory that we created earlier.

title: 1Â  Using a Terminal
text:
2.9 Parent directories
Now letâ€™s get crazy. Letâ€™s list the files â€œaboveâ€ where we are.

Type and run this command.

$ ls ../
Remember I said that two dots means the parent directory? This should show you the list of files and folders in your home directory.

Now, confirm where you are:

pwd
Which should still be icj. So you had listed the files for the folder â€œaboveâ€ you.

title: 1Â  Using a Terminal
text:
2.10 Tab completion
If you are doing ls or cd or otherwise referencing a path in the terminal, you donâ€™t have to type the whole word for each directory. If you are trying to list the contents of â€œnewdirectoryâ€, then start with ls newd and then hit tab, and it will finish out the path as ls newdirectory. This is SUPER handy and you should use it often. Like all the time.






Important



Tab completion makes your programming live so much easier, and it works in more places than in our terminal. Use this skill.

title: 1Â  Using a Terminal
text:
2.11 On the right path

2.11.1 Relative paths
You can ls files or cd into any directory relative to your current working directory using ../ to move â€œupâ€ the folder structure and then use the name of the new directory to move inside it. So a path like this: ls ../../Users/Cory is to travel up two folders, then into Users then into Cory and then list all the files there.
This is very powerful in programming, because you might be writing and testing code on your own computer, but then run the program on another computer, so if file01.py needs to talk to file02.py, you donâ€™t want to hard-code a path like http://utdata.cmcdonald.com/scripts/file02.py, because you might not always be on utdata.cmcdonald.com. If itâ€™s in the same folder, you could use file02.py or ./file02.py.


2.11.2 Root-relative paths
You can reference the â€œrootâ€ or the top level of whatever server or machine you are on even if you donâ€™t know the name of it, by starting your path with a slash like this: /scripts/file01.py. Thatâ€™s called a root-relative path. If you know the root-relative path to a file or folder, you can always find it no matter what directory you are currently in. We wonâ€™t use this much in this class.


2.11.3 Absolute paths
An absolute path includes the domain or computer name. If I reference http://utdata.cmcdonald.com/scripts/file01.py in my code or script, it will only work if Iâ€™m on utdata.cmcdonald.com. If I move that script to another computer or server, it will still try to pull from utdata.cmcdonald.com instead of the version on the new computer. We avoid using absolute paths in this class for this reason.


2.11.4 The home directory shortcut
There is also a path shortcut called ~/ that stands for â€œthe home directory of the logged in personâ€. You might see that referenced in paths like ~/Documents/ but that would really take me to /Users/ccm346/Documents/ on my computer. But whatâ€™s cool is the same ~/Documents/ path works on YOUR computer, even though your user directory name is different.

3.3 Getting Started with Git, GitHub, and RStudio

3.3.1 Step 1: Install the Tools
Before we can get started, weâ€™ll need to make sure that our computers (often referred to as our local machines) are set up correctly. Letâ€™s do that by completing the following steps:

Install Git

Go to: https://git-scm.com/downloads
Download and install Git
Default install settings are fine

Sign up for a Github account:

Go to: https://github.com
Click Sign up
Choose a username and email youâ€™ll remember (youâ€™ll use this in Git config)





3.3.2 Step 2: Set Up Git in the Terminal
After installing Git, youâ€™ll need to configure it with your name and email. Open the terminal (you can find this in RStudio under the â€œTerminalâ€ tab) and run the following commands:
First, weâ€™ll set up our username.
About Git usernames:
Usernames are what git uses to associate your work with your identity. For now, just know that the name you set here will be visible in any work you send to Github. You do not have to use your real name.
Setting your Git username
Run the following command from your Terminal, replacing â€œYour Nameâ€ with the username youâ€™d like to use (including the quotation marks):
git config --global user.name "Your Name"
Check to see if you successfully set your name by running:
git config user.name
You should see a Terminal response message with the username you entered. If you didnâ€™t get the response expected, then try again. Remember, be careful about punctuation.
Once you have your username set properly, weâ€™ll set your email.






Caution



Remember, the username you set here will be visible (read: public) in any future commits you push to GitHub. If you choose to use a nickname or alias instead of your real name, keep it professional enough that you wouldnâ€™t mind a future employer or colleague seeing it if you needed to share your work.


Setting your git email
The email you enter needs to match the one you used to setup your Github account.
Set your user email by running the following command, replacing â€œyour.email@example.comâ€ with your Github email:
git config --global user.email "your.email@example.com"






Important



Your git email should be the same as the one you use on GitHub so your commits will be linked correctly

3.1 You can think of Git like a very smart â€œsave gameâ€ system for your projects. Unlike in Google docs, our versions arenâ€™t automatically saved for us. We have to tell our computers when and how to save a new version.
How GitHub fits into this:
GitHub is a website that hosts Git repositories (your project + its history) online.
It lets you:

Store your Git project safely in the cloud.
Share your project with others.
Collaborate with other people (even if they are far away).
Keep a backup in case your computer crashes.

If Git is your notebook where you track all your work, GitHub is like an online library where you can store a copy of your notebook â€” and invite others to read it or even help you write it.

In short:

Git = tool you use on your computer to track changes.
GitHub = website where you can upload (and share) your Git projects.

If we want Git to start watching our files and keeping track of our changes, we have to make sure Git is connected to our project. To do this, we need initialize git inside of our Quarto project.
To initialize Git in your Quarto project, Click the Terminal tab in RStudio (usually lower-left)
Inside Terminal, type the following command and run it (by hitting enter):
git init
In basic terms, this tells Git â€œI want you to start tracking this folder.â€
If it works, youâ€™ll see Terminal respond with something like:
Initialized empty Git repository in /Users/yourname/my-quarto-project/.git/

3.3 ğŸ—‚ï¸ Step 3: Tell Git What Files to Track
Now that weâ€™ve let Git know that we want it to start watching our project, weâ€™ll also need to tell git what files we would like it to keep track of.
First, letâ€™s ask Git what it â€œseesâ€ in our project folder by running:
git status
Terminal will return something like the following as a response:
On branch main

No commits yet

Untracked files:
  (use "git add <file>..." to include in what will be committed)
        .Rproj.user/
        .quarto/
        _quarto.yml
        my-first-git-project.Rproj
        my-first-git-project.html
        my-first-git-project.qmd
        my-first-git-project_files/

nothing added to commit but untracked files present (use "git add" to track)
Now, letâ€™s breakdown what this all means:

On branch main: Youâ€™re working on the main branch â€” the default starting line of development.
No commits yet: This means Git is ready, but you havenâ€™t saved any versions yet.
Untracked Files: These are files Git sees in your folder, but itâ€™s not saving changes to them yet. Theyâ€™re marked in red in the terminal and the RStudio Git tab.

In the next step, weâ€™ll learn how to tell Git what files weâ€™d like it to track and which files to ignore.

2.2 Step 2: Set Up Git in the Terminal
After installing Git, youâ€™ll need to configure it with your name and email. Open the terminal (you can find this in RStudio under the â€œTerminalâ€ tab) and run the following commands:
First, weâ€™ll set up our username.
About Git usernames:
Usernames are what git uses to associate your work with your identity. For now, just know that the name you set here will be visible in any work you send to Github. You do not have to use your real name.
Setting your Git username
Run the following command from your Terminal, replacing â€œYour Nameâ€ with the username youâ€™d like to use (including the quotation marks):
git config --global user.name "Your Name"
Check to see if you successfully set your name by running:
git config user.name
You should see a Terminal response message with the username you entered. If you didnâ€™t get the response expected, then try again. Remember, be careful about punctuation.
Once you have your username set properly, weâ€™ll set your email.






Caution



Remember, the username you set here will be visible (read: public) in any future commits you push to GitHub. If you choose to use a nickname or alias instead of your real name, keep it professional enough that you wouldnâ€™t mind a future employer or colleague seeing it if you needed to share your work.


Setting your git email
The email you enter needs to match the one you used to setup your Github account.
Set your user email by running the following command, replacing â€œyour.email@example.comâ€ with your Github email:
git config --global user.email "your.email@example.com"






Important



Your git email should be the same as the one you use on GitHub so your commits will be linked correctly

title: 6Â  Gitignore files
text:
6.1.0.1 ğŸ” Whoa â€” why is .html showing up?
Good question! That .html file is the rendered output from Quarto. It changes every time you click â€œRender,â€ and you usually donâ€™t want to save it in Git. Itâ€™s like saving every draft printout of a paper â€” not helpful.


6.1.1 ğŸ™ˆ Introducing .gitignore
In a GitHub project, there are several types of files and directories that you typically want to want to keep out of our repositories to keep things clean, secure, and easy to manage. What you ignore will depend on the type of project and the coding languages youâ€™re using, but all Github projects use a file called .gitignore to let Git know what to ignore.
For R and Quarto projects, this will include the following files types: 1. Session and history files: .Rhistory, .RData, .Rproj.user/ 2. Knitting files: .utf8.md, .knit.md 3. Output/render folders: *_files/ ,_site/, _book/ 4. Editor and IDE Config Files .Rproj.user/
Letâ€™s make a .gitignore now using the command line. Type the following code into the Terminal to make your new file using the touch command:
touch .gitignore
Then open .gitignore in the Files pane in RStudio. If you donâ€™t see the .gitignore in your file pane, you may need to refresh by clicking the icon at the top right of the file pane.
Once you have your blank .gitignore file open, add the following lines:
*.html 
_site/ 
.Rproj.user/
Letâ€™s break down what each of these mean:

*.html : Ignore all .html files (rendered outputs)
_site/: Ignore the entire contents of the _site folder
.Rproj.user/: Ignore the hidden RStudio files

Save the file, then check your Git status again:
git status
Now the .html file should be gone from the list of red files Git â€œseesâ€ because weâ€™ve told it to ignore these types of files. âœ¨
Before moving forward, letâ€™s add a few more things to the .gitignore to cover all our bases.
Copy and paste the following code into your .gitignore file.
# R
.Rhistory
.RData
.Rproj.user/

# Quarto
*.html
*_files/
*.utf8.md
*.knit.md
_site/
_book/

# System
.DS_Store
Save and close the file.

title: 5Â  Pushing to Github
text:
5.1.1 ğŸ›  Step 1: Create a Repository on GitHub

Go to github.com and log in.
Click the + in the upper right corner â†’ choose â€œNew repositoryâ€.
Fill out the form:

Repository name: Use the same name as your project folder (e.g.Â my-quarto-project)
Leave Description blank or optional
Leave the box unchecked that says â€œInitialize this repository with a READMEâ€ (Weâ€™ll add this on our own later)
Click Create repository


Youâ€™ll now see a page with instructions on how to connect your local folder to this GitHub repository.



5.1.2 ğŸ”— Step 2: Connect Your Local Git Project to GitHub
In your terminal (inside your project folder), run the following:
git remote add origin https://github.com/YOUR-USERNAME/YOUR-REPO-NAME.git
Replace the URL with the one GitHub gives you â€” it should look something like:
git remote add origin https://github.com/jane-doe/my-quarto-project.git
Then set the main branch name and push by running
git branch -M main git push -u origin main
If it asks for your username and password, you may need to set up a personal access token â€” GitHub no longer allows passwords for command-line pushes. Weâ€™ll walk through that in the appendix if you get stuck.

5.1.2.1 ğŸ§© Recap: What Do These Commands Do?
Letâ€™s breakdown what we just did in the last step:

git remote add origin ...: Tells Git where your online repository lives (on GitHub).
git branch -M main: Renames your current branch to main (standard practice on GitHub).
git push -u origin main: Uploads your local commits to GitHub and sets up a link between your local main branch and the main branch on GitHub.


ğŸ‰ Congratulations: Now your project is on GitHub!

5.1.3 ğŸ¯ Exercise 2: Visit Your GitHub Project
Go to your repository page on GitHub. You should see all your project files, including .qmd, .gitignore, etc.
âœ… Your project is now tracked by Git and backed up on GitHub.
Pay attention to information showing in the file list. Youâ€™ll see some helpful information about the project
In the Header area: 1. Which user made the most recent commit 2. The commit message 3. The commit number 4. The timestamp of the commit In the file list: 5. The commit message and timestamp will show from the most recent update made to each file or folder.
ğŸ§  Not every file will update with each git push. Git only keeps track of changes, so these timestamps help you track when updates were last made different parts of your project!

section: 6.2 ğŸ› ï¸ Step 1: Make a Small Change
text:
6.2 ğŸ› ï¸ Step 1: Make a Small Change
Letâ€™s open your Quarto file you made in Chapter 1 (e.g., 01-index.qmd) and make a couple changes.
Replace the auto-generated text and code blocks in the file with the following
---
title: "Intro to Git"
format: html
---

# Summary

Here is a summary of the `mtcars` dataset.
Under the summary header and description, add a code chunk with the following:

Save the file. Now check the status in your Terminal again by running:
git status
Youâ€™ll see something like as a Terminal response:
On branch main
Your branch is up to date with 'origin/main'.

Changes not staged for commit:
  (use "git add <file>..." to update what will be committed)
  (use "git restore <file>..." to discard changes in working directory)
        modified:   01-index.qmd
Letâ€™s break this down :
The red text tells us that Git sees something was modified in your 01-index.qmd. Itâ€™s under the Changes not staged for commit: section, which tells us that Git hasnâ€™t staged it yet (so it wonâ€™t be saved in the next commit).

title: 6Â  Making and pushing changes
text:
6.3 ğŸ“¥ Step 3: Stage the Change
We want to tell Git, â€œHey, save this file in the next snapshot.â€
Weâ€™ll do this by adding the modified file to the snapshot. We can do that by running:

Now youâ€™ll see your file in green and following message:

ğŸ‰ Great! The change is now staged.

text:
6.4 Step 4: Commit the Change
Now, weâ€™ll save the snapshot (in Gitâ€™s memory). When we do so, weâ€™ll want to include a descriptive commit message noting what we changed.
Type something like the following and git enter
git commit -m "Add summary of mtcars dataset"
A few best practices for commit messages:
âœ… Use present tense: "Add summary of...", not "Added..."
âœ… Keep it short but descriptive
âœ… Think: â€œWhat changed in this version?â€
ğŸ•µï¸â€â™€ï¸ Good commit messages make it easier for you and others to pick up where you left off. If something breaks during an update or you need to go back to a prior version, commit messages will help your retrace your steps.

Note



You may be wondering why our push command is shorter than it was last time. In our last push, we needed to connect our remote main branch to the remote Github repository. Since weâ€™re already connected our Quarto project to Github and set our branch to main, we can just use the git push command now.
